{{Infobox Airline |airline = Air Kasaï |logo = Air Kasaï logo.png |logo_size = 123 |fleet_size = 5 |destinations = 21 |IATA = - |ICAO = - |callsign = - |parent = |company_slogan = |founded = 1983 |headquarters = [[N'Dolo Airport]]
[[Kinshasa]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |key_people = |hubs = [[N'Dolo Airport]] |secondary_hubs = [[Mbandaka]], [[Tshikapa]], [[Kananga]] |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |website = [http://www.airkasai.cd/ www.airkasai.cd] }} [[File:Air Kasai.JPG|thumb|Previous logo]] '''Air Kasaï''' is an [[airline]] with its head office on the property of [[N'Dolo Airport]] in [[Barumbu]], [[Kinshasa]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]."[http://www.airkasai.cd/contact.php Nos Contacts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307014324/http://www.airkasai.cd/contact.php |date=7 March 2013 }}." Air Kasaï. Retrieved on 4 March 2013. It operates charter services within [[Africa]]. Its main base is [[N'Dolo Airport]], Kinshasa.{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | pages= 58–59 | date= 2007-03-27}} The airline is banned from operating in the European Union, as any other airline in the country is, and it is on the [[list of air carriers banned in the European Union]]. {{cite web|title=List of airlines subject to an operating ban or operational restrictions within the European Union |url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/modes/air/safety/air-ban/doc/list_en.pdf |work=European Commission for Transport |publisher=[[European Commission]] |accessdate=11 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CgKliGs4?url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/modes/air/safety/air-ban/doc/list_en.pdf |archivedate=5 December 2012 }} ==History== The airline was established in 1983 and was formerly known as TAC - Transport Aérien Congo and TAZ - Transport Aérien Zaïrois. It is a Swedish owned company. In March 2006, Air Kasaï was officially banned from operating in the whole [[European Union|EU]], plus [[Norway]] and [[Switzerland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eublacklist.com/languages/english.html|title=EU Blacklist|website=Eublacklist.com|accessdate=31 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404063148/http://www.eublacklist.com/languages/english.html|archive-date=4 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Destinations== Air Kasaï serves the following destinations (as of April 2012):{{Cite web|url=http://timetablist.blogspot.co.uk/2011/06/air-kasai-international-routes-2011.html|title=Air Kasai: The International Schedule, 2011|website=Timetablist.blogspot.co.uk|access-date=2017-08-16}} {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background-color: #FFE6BD"|[Base]||[[Airline hub|Base]] |- |} {|class="wikitable sortable" ! City ! Country ! Region ! Airport |- |[[Beni, Democratic Republic of the Congo|Beni]]||{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}}||[[Central Africa]]||[[Wageni Airport]] |- |[[Bunia]] |{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[Bunia Airport]] |- |[[Entebbe]] |{{Flag|Uganda}} |[[East Africa]] |[[Entebbe International Airport]] |- |[[Goma]] |{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[Goma International Airport]] |- |[[Kinshasa]]| |{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |style="background-color: #FFE6BD"|[[N'djili Airport]] [Base] |- |[[Kinshasa]] |{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[N'Dolo Airport]] [Base] |- |[[Libreville]] |{{Flag|Gabon}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[Libreville International Airport|Libreville Leon M'ba International Airport]] |- |[[Lubumbashi]] |{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[Lubumbashi International Airport]] |- |[[Pointe-Noire]] |{{Flag|Republic of the Congo}} |[[Central Africa]] |[[Pointe Noire Airport|Antonio Agostinho Neto International Airport]] |} ==Fleet== The Air Kasaï fleet consists of the following aircraft (as of April 2014){{Cite web |url=http://www.airkasai.cd/compagnie.php |title=Compagnie |access-date=4 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629102412/http://airkasai.cd/compagnie.php |archive-date=29 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}
{| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="white-space:nowrap; border-collapse:collapse" |+ '''Air Kasaï Fleet''' |- bgcolor=red ! Aircraft ! In Fleet |- |[[Antonov An-26]] |align="center"|1 |- |[[ATR 72]] |align="center"|1 |- |[[Let L-410 Turbolet]] |align="center"|1 |- |[[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-230]] |align="center"|1 |- |[[Antonov An-2]] |align="center"|1 |- !Total !5 |}
==Media== In March 2014 Air Kasaï was featured in the [[Vice News]] Episode: Russian Pilots of the Congo.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=epYiIMl4W4U ==Incidents and accidents== On 9 September 2005, an Air Kasaï [[Antonov An-26|Antonov An-26B]] [[2005 Air Kasai Antonov An-26B crash|crashed]] in the [[Republic of the Congo]] 50 kilometers (31 miles) north of [[Brazzaville]], killing all 13 people (four crew members and nine passengers) on board."[http://english.people.com.cn/200509/11/eng20050911_207929.html 13 killed in plane crash in Congo]." ''[[People's Daily]]''."[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=qw1126584901951B252 Bodies to be sent to DRC after plane crash]." ''[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]]''. On 27 July 2018, an [[Antonov 2]] crashed on take-off from an airstrip near [[Kamako]], killing 5 of 7 occupantshttps://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20180727-0 ==See also== {{Portal|Democratic Republic of the Congo|Aviation}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.airkasai.cd/}} {{fr icon}} {{Airlines of the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Air Kasai}} [[Category:Airlines of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1983]] [[Category:Companies based in Kinshasa]] {{africa-airline-stub}} {{DRCongo-stub}}

'''Bafatá Airport''' {{Airport codes||GGBF}} is an airport serving [[Bafatá]] in [[Guinea-Bissau]]. The dirt runway doubles as Av. Brasil<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/@12.177581,-14.653401,3a,75y,90t/data=!3m5!1e2!3m3!1s38209362!2e1!3e10|title=Google Maps|website=Google Maps|language=en|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/@12.177455,-14.653745,3a,75y,90t/data=!3m5!1e2!3m3!1s38210690!2e1!3e10|title=Google Maps|website=Google Maps|language=en|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> and may have vehicular traffic.

{{unreferenced|date=November 2016}} The '''Cabinet Kretschmann II''' is the government of the German [[States of Germany|state]] of [[Baden-Württemberg]] which has been in office since 12 May 2016, following the [[Baden-Württemberg state election, 2016|2016 Baden-Württemberg state elections]]. Succeeding the [[Cabinet Kretschmann I]], the Cabinet is headed by Prime Minister [[Winfried Kretschmann]] again and is formed by a coalition of the [[Alliance '90/The Greens|Green Party]] and the [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|Christian Democrats]]. It is the first state-level government of the two parties to be headed by a member of the Green Party in German history. Five cabinet members are from the CDU and seven cabinet positions as well as the office of State Ministry of Baden-Württemberg are held by members of the Green Party. Kretschmann was elected Minister President on 12 May 2016. The officials were sworn into office on the same day. Cabinet members hold the office of Ministers of their respective portfolio, except where this is specified otherwise. {| class="wikitable" !width="330" bgcolor="#FFDEAD" align="left" |Office !width="230" bgcolor="#FFDEAD" align="left" |Name !width="120" bgcolor="#FFDEAD" align="left" |Party !width="180" bgcolor="#FFDEAD" align="left" |Secretary of State |- | [[Minister President]] | [[Winfried Kretschmann]] || [[Alliance '90/The Greens|Green Party]] || [[Klaus-Peter Murawski]]
State Minister in the Ministry of State, Head of State Chancellery |----- | Deputy Prime Minister;
Interior, Digitalisation and Migration | [[Thomas Strobl]] || [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]] || |----- | Finance | [[Edith Sitzmann]] || Green Party || [[Gisela Splett]] (Green Party) |----- | Education, Youth, and Sports | [[Susanne Eisenmann]] || CDU || [[Volker Schebesta]] (CDU) |----- | Science, Research, and Arts | [[Theresia Bauer]] || Green Party || [[Petra Olschowski]] |----- | Environment, Climate, and Energy Industry | [[Franz Untersteller]] || Green Party || [[Andre Baumann]] |----- | Economics, Labor, and Housing | [[Nicole Hoffmeister-Kraut]] || CDU || [[Katrin Schütz]] (CDU) |----- | Social Affairs and Integration | [[Manfred Lucha]] || Green Party || [[Bärbl Mielich]] (Green Party) |----- | Rural Affairs and Consumer Protection | [[Peter Hauk]] || CDU || [[Friedlinde Gurr-Hirsch]] (CDU) |----- | Justice and European Affairs | [[Guido Wolf (politician)|Guido Wolf]] || CDU || – |----- | Transportation | [[Winfried Hermann]] || Green Party || – |----- | State Counsellor for Civil Society and Civic Participation | [[Gisela Erler]] || Green Party || – |----- |} ==External links== *[http://stm.baden-wuerttemberg.de/de/service/presse/pressemitteilung/pid/die-landesregierung/ Overview of the state government] [[Category:Cabinets of Baden-Württemberg|Kretschmann II]] [[Category:2016 establishments in Germany]] {{germany-stub}}

60,000 deaths{{sfn|Clodfelter|2017|pp=170}} }} The '''Coalition Wars''' (French: ''Guerres de Coalitions'', German: ''Koalitionskriege'', Dutch: ''Coalitieoorlogen'' etc.) were a series of seven wars waged by various [[military alliance]]s, known as the Coalitions, between great [[Europe]]an powers against [[French Revolution|Revolutionary France]], and from 1796 onwards General and later Emperor [[Napoleon Bonaparte]].{{Cite book |last=Grab |first=Alexander |date=2003 |title=Napoleon and the Transformation of Europe |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=d48dBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1 |location= |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] |page=1 |isbn=9781403937575 |accessdate=27 May 2016}}{{nl icon}} Encarta-encyclopedie Winkler Prins (1993–2002) s.v. "coalitieoorlogen". Microsoft Corporation/Het Spectrum. The Coalition Wars were: *[[War of the First Coalition]] (April 1792 – October 1797) *[[War of the Second Coalition]] (1798/99 – 1801/02) *[[War of the Third Coalition]] (1803/05 – December 1805) *[[War of the Fourth Coalition]] (October 1806 – July 1807) *[[War of the Fifth Coalition]] (April – October 1809) *[[War of the Sixth Coalition]] (March 1813 – May 1814) *[[War of the Seventh Coalition]], also known as the [[Hundred Days]] (March – July 1815) == Terminology == === Etymology === One of the first usages of the term can be found in the 1803 [[Tribunat]] report, titled ''Résultats des guerres, des négociations et des traités qui ont préced́é et suivi la coalition contre la France'' ("Results of the Wars, Negotiations and Treaties that preceded and followed the Coalition against France"). About the situation in April 1793, when General [[Dumouriez]] had just been [[Battle of Neerwinden (1793)|defeated at Neerwinden]] and defected to Austria, causing despair in France, it states: "Les événements de cette époque sont les plus pénibles à décrire de tous ceux qui ont signalé ''les guerres de la coalition''." ("The events of that time are the most painful to describe of all those that marked ''the wars of the coalition''."){{Cite book |author=Arnould |date=1803 |title=Résultats des guerres, des négociations et des traités qui ont préced́é et suivi la coalition contre la France |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DeYzAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA197 |location=Paris |publisher=Badouin |accessdate=27 May 2016 |language=fr}} In January 1805, the ''Salzburger Intelligenzblatt'' was one of the first to number the Coalition Wars when it discussed "Das Staatsinteresse von Baiern bei dem dritten Koalitions-Kriege" ("The national interest of Bavaria in the Third Coalition War").{{Cite journal |last= |first= |date=January 1805 |title=Intelligenzblatt von Salzburg: 1805 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cYxEAAAAcAAJ&pg=RA1-PA143 |journal=Salzburger Intelligenzblatt |publisher=Verlag des Zeitungs-Comtoirs |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=143–4 |accessdate=27 May 2016 |language=de}} Although the Third Coalition had been formed by that time, war had not yet broken out; the Austrian newspaper discussed why the neighbouring [[Electorate of Bavaria]] was likely to side with the French Republic rather than the Austrian-led Coalition. On 30 September 1805, a few days after the launch of the [[Ulm Campaign]], Emperor Napoleon addressed his troops in Strasbourg, starting his speech with the words: "Soldats, la guerre de la troisième coalition est commencée." ("Soldiers, the war of the third coalition has begun."){{Cite book |last=Guizot |first=François |authorlink1=François Guizot |date=2015 |title=L'histoire de France depuis 1789 jusqu'en 1848 racontée à mes petits-enfants |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VimiBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT491 |location= |publisher=Primento |page=491 |isbn=9782335028768 |accessdate=27 May 2016 |language=fr}} === Compared to other terms === [[File:Nach der Völckerschlacht1.jpg|300px|thumb|The Sixth Coalition's monarchs, [[Alexander I of Russia|Tsar Alexander I of Russia]], [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Francis I of Austria]] and [[Frederick William III of Prussia|King Frederick William III of Prussia]], are informed that the French army has been [[Battle of Leipzig|defeated at Leipzig]].]] The term is distinct from "[[French Revolutionary Wars]]", which covers any war involving Revolutionary France between 1792 and 1799, when Napoleon seized power with the [[Coup of 18 Brumaire]] (9 November 1799), which is usually considered the end of the French Revolution. Since the War of the Second Coalition (1798–1802) had already begun when Napoleon seized power, the war as a whole may or may not be counted amongst the French Revolutionary Wars, which therefore may end in 1799, 1801 ([[Treaty of Lunéville]]) or 1802 ([[Treaty of Amiens]]). It also differs from "[[Napoleonic Wars]]", which is variously defined as covering any war involving France ruled by Napoleon between 1799 and 1815 (which includes the War of the Second Coalition, 1798–1802), or not commencing until the [[War of the Third Coalition]] (1803/05, depending on periodisation). In the latter case, historians do not term the War of the Second Coalition "Napoleonic", since Napoleon did not initiate it himself, but merely "inherited" it from the Revolutionary French Directory which he overthrew during the war. Because it only pertains to wars involving any of the Coalition parties, not all wars counted amongst the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars are considered "Coalition Wars". For example, the [[French invasion of Switzerland]] (1798, between the First and Second Coalition), the [[Stecklikrieg]] (1802, between the Second and Third Coalition) and the [[French invasion of Russia]] (1812, between the Fifth and Sixth Coalition) were not "Coalition Wars", since France fought against a single opponent. {{Timeline Coalition Wars}} == Coalition parties == The main European powers who forged the various anti-French Coalitions were [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]], [[Russian Empire|Russia]], [[Austrian Empire|Austria]] and [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]], although except for Great Britain not all of them were involved in every Coalition. Smaller powers that occasionally joined the Coalitions include [[Spanish Empire|Spain]], [[Kingdom of Naples|Naples]], [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Piedmont–Sardinia]], the [[Dutch Republic]], the [[Ottoman Empire]], [[Portuguese Empire|Portugal]], [[Kingdom of Sweden|Sweden]], [[Denmark–Norway]] and various German and Italian states. The First until Fifth Coalitions fell apart when one or more parties were defeated by France and were forced to leave the alliance, and sometimes became French allies; the Sixth and Seventh were dissolved after Napoleon was defeated in 1814 and 1815 and a new balance of power was established between the parties at the [[Congress of Vienna]]. {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="font-size:90%; margin:1em auto 1em auto" |+ Members of each Coalition ! Members ! width="120px" | [[First coalition|First]]{{-}}(1792–97) ! width="120px" | [[Second coalition|Second]]{{-}}(1798–1802) ! width="120px" | [[Third Coalition|Third]]{{-}}(1803–06) ! width="120px" | [[Fourth coalition|Fourth]]{{-}}(1806–07) ! width="120px" | [[Fifth coalition|Fifth]]{{-}}(1809) ! width="120px" | [[Sixth coalition|Sixth]]{{-}}(1812–14) ! width="120px" | [[Seventh {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Monaco}} "Comme on s'aime" | image = | caption = | year = 1972 | country = Monaco | artist = Peter McLane
& Anne-Marie Godart | as = | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = Raymond Bernard | lyricist = [[Jean Dréjac]] | conductor = Raymond Bernard | place = 16th | points = 65 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1972mc from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Un banc, un arbre, une rue | prev_link = Un banc, un arbre, une rue | next = Un train qui part | next_link = Un train qui part }} '''"Comme on s'aime"''' ([[English language|English]] translation: "How We Love Each Other") was the [[Monaco|Monegasque]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972]], performed in [[French language|French]] by the duo [[Peter McLane]] and [[Anne-Marie Godart]]. The song is a duet, in which the singers describe the unending devotion they have for one another. They explain that, despite it being ''"the same old subject"'', they still find their love fresh each day. The song was performed fifteenth on the night, following [[Sweden]]'s [[Family Four]] with "[[Härliga sommardag]]" and preceding [[Belgium]]'s [[Serge & Christine Ghisoland]] with "[[À la folie ou pas du tout]]". At the close of voting, it had received 65 points, placing 16th in a field of 18. It was succeeded as Monegasque representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1973|1973 Contest]] by [[Marie-France Dufour|Marie]] with "[[Un train qui part]]". ==Sources and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=288 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1972] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1972mc Detailed info and lyrics, The Diggiloo Thrush, "Comme on s'aime".] {{Monaco in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1972}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Monaco]] [[Category:Vocal duets]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1972]] [[Category:1972 songs]] {{monaco-stub}}
