{{Unreferenced|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Operation Lucky Alphonse |date=7 June 1956 - 23 June 1956 |place=[[Troodos Mountains]], [[Cyprus]] |result= 17 EOKA members were captured, and the EOKA group was broken and no longer posed a threat. |combatant1= |combambatant2= |commander1=
[[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|22px]] Brigadier [[Geoffrey Baker]] |commander2=
[[File:Flag of Cyprus.svg|22px]] Colonel [[Georgios Grivas]] |strength1= 40,000 |strength2= 300 |casualties1= 25 (none directly by EOKA) |casualties2= 17 captured }} {{Campaignbox Cyprus Emergency}} '''Operation Lucky Alphonse''' was a [[British Armed Forces]] operation that occurred during the [[EOKA]] insurgency in Cyprus. The British Army lost 25 men, mostly as a result of road accidents (7) and a forest fire that killed 13 men of the [[Gordon Highlanders]], 5 Norfolks and two from the Parachute Regiment. ==Units== *Units already stationed in the [[Troodos Mountains|Troodos]] Area{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} **The Parachute Regiment **The [[Royal Marines]] **The Gordon Highlanders *Supporting Units **The [[King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry]] **The [[South Staffordshire Regiment]] **The [[Royal Norfolk Regiment]] **The [[Royal Horse Guards]] **The [[RAF Regiment]] **[[HMS Diamond]] **C Company of the 1st Battalion, The [[Highland Light Infantry]] ==References== {{reflist}} *David Carter, [http://www.britains-smallwars.com/cyprus/Davidcarter/fire/PaphosFire.html The Tragedy of Lucky Alphonse (The Paphos Fire)], Britain's Small Wars, 2005 ==See also== *[[Modern history of Cyprus]] {{coord missing|Cyprus}} [[Category:Military operations involving the United Kingdom|Lucky Alphonse]] [[Category:Cyprus Emergency]] [[Category:1956 in Cyprus]] [[Category:June 1956 events]] {{europe-mil-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Diocese | name = Qui Nhon | latin = Dioecesis Quinhonensis | local = Giáo phận Quy Nhơn | image = Nha tho Quy Nhon.JPG | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Our Lady of Assumption | coat = <!-- Coat of arms file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | coat_size = | coat_alt = | flag = <!-- Flag file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | flag_size = | flag_alt = <!---- Locations ----> | country = [[Vietnam]] | territory = | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Huế|Huê]] | metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Huế|Huê]] | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = <!-- Use {{coord}} --> <!---- Statistics ----> | area_km2 = 17,087 | area_sqmi = <!-- Area in square miles, automatically converted --> | area_footnotes = | population = 3,780,700 | population_as_of = 2010 | catholics = 68,355 | catholics_percent = 1.8 | parishes = | churches = <!-- Number of churches in the diocese --> | congregations = <!-- Number of congregations in the diocese --> | schools = <!-- Number of church supported schools in the diocese --> | members = <!-- Number of members in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | sui_iuris_church = [[Latin Church]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = | cathedral = Cathedral of the Assumption in [[Qui Nhơn]] | cocathedral = | patron = <!-- Patron saint(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | patron_title = <!-- Use to override the default label "Patron saint" --> | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} <!-- DO NOT CHANGE. This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = Matthieu Nguyên Van Khôi | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = [[Joseph Nguyễn Chí Linh]] | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = Pierre Nguyên Soan <small>Bishop Emeritus (1999-2012)</small> <!---- Map ----> | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = [http://gpquinhon.org/qn/ Website of the Diocese] | footnotes = }} The '''diocese of Qui Nhơn''' (also referred to as the '''diocese of Quy Nhơn'''; {{lang-la|Dioecesis Quinhonensis|links=no}}; {{lang-vi|Giáo phận Qui Nhơn|links=no}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] diocese in central [[Vietnam]]. The Bishop is Pierre Nguyên Soan, since 1999; Father Matthieu Nguyen Van Khoi, pastor of Assumption Cathedral in [[Quy Nhơn]] and professor at the "Maria Stella" Seminary of [[Nha Trang]], was appointed Coadjutor Bishop-elect of the diocese by Pope Benedict XVI on December 31, 2009. He will be ordained at a later date; as coadjutor bishop to Bishop Soan, he serves as an [[auxiliary bishop]] and [[vicar general]] of the diocese but also, by canon law, has the right to automatically succeed him upon his death, retirement, or incapacitation.
The creation of the diocese in present form was declared November 24, 1960.
The diocese covers an area of 16,200 km², and is a [[suffragan diocese]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Huế|Archdiocese of Huế]].
By 2004, the diocese of Qui Nhơn had about 62,520 believers (1.7% of the population), 70 [[priest]]s and 36 [[parish]]es.<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon>[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dquyn.html Catholic Hierarchy: "Diocese of Quy Nhon"] retrieved November 8, 2015</ref>
Assumption Cathedral in Quy Nhơn town has been assigned as the [[Cathedral]] of the [[diocese]].<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/churches/data/cathVN.htm#chk GCatholic.org]</ref>
==Ordinaries==
===Vicariate Apostolic of Cochin=== Erected 1659<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon /> *[[Pierre Lambert de la Motte]] [[M.E.P.]] (1658–1679) *[[Guillaume Mahot]] M.E.P. (1680–1684) *[[François Perez]] (1687–1728) *[[Alexandre de Alexandris]] (1728–1738) *[[Arnaud-François Lefèbvre]] M.E.P. (1741–1760) *[[Guillaume Piguel]] M.E.P. (1762–1771) *[[Pierre Pigneau de Behaine|Pierre-Joseph-Georges Pigneau de Béhaine]], M.E.P. (1771–1799) *[[Jean Labartette]] M.E.P (1799–1823) *[[Jean-Louis Taberd]] M.E.P (1827–1840) *[[Etienne-Théodore Cuénot]] M.E.P (1840–1844)
===Vicariate Apostolic of Eastern Cochin=== Separated March 2, 1844<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon /> The separated entity, Vicariate Apostolic of Western Cochin, would later become the Vicariate Apostolic of Saigon and then the [[Archdiocese of Saigon]].<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon /> *Etienne-Théodore Cuénot M.E.P. (1844–1861) *[[Eugène-Étienne Charbonnier]] M.E.P. (1864–1878) *[[Louis-Marie Galibert]] M.E.P. (1879–1883) *[[Désiré-François-Xavier Van Camelbeke]] M.E.P. (1884–1901) *[[Damien Grangeon]] M.E.P. (1902–1924)
===Vicariate Apostolic of Quinhon=== Renamed December 3, 1924<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon /> *Damien Grangeon MEP (1924–1929) *[[Augustin-Marie Tardieu]] M.E.P. (1930–1942) *[[Raymond-Marie-Marcel Piquet]] M.E.P. (1943–1957)
===Diocese of Qui Nhon=== Elevated November 24, 1960<ref name=CathHierDiocesQuyNhon /> *[[Pierre Marie Pham-Ngoc-Chi]] (1960–1963) *[[Dominique Hoàng-Packwagen-Doàn]] O.P. (1963–1974) *[[Paul Huynh Dông Các]] (1974–1999) *[[Pierre Nguyên Soan]] (1999–2012) *[[Matthieu Nguyên Van Khôi]] (2012–present)

revision.text:
[[File:Drought.jpg|thumb|Takyr (playa) in Sonora Desert (USA)]]
'''Takir''' ('''Takyr''') ({{lang-ru|Такыр}}, originally from [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]] or another [[Turkic language]]) meaning "smooth, even, or bare", is a type of relief occurring in the deserts of [[Central Asia]], similar to a [[Salt pan (geology)|salt flat]] in the southwestern United States. A takyr is usually formed in a shallow depressed area with a heavy clay soil, which is submerged by water after seasonal rains. After the water evaporates, a dried [[soil crust|crust]] with fissures forms on the surface. The crust is often colonized by [[wiktionary:Filamentous|filamentous]] [[cyanobacteria]].
In the southwestern U.S. "takyrs" are known as "playas" or "salt flats", in Arab countries as "sabha".
== Further reading == * Jayne Belnap, Otto Ludwig Lange. "Biological [[Soil Crust]]s: Structure, Function, and Management". Springer, 2001, {{ISBN|3-540-43757-6}}. Page 90, Chapter 7.5, "Central Asia Takyr".
[[Category:Salt flats]]
{{CAsia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} The '''World Sanskrit conference''' is an international conference organised at various locations globally. It has been held in [[North America]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]] and [[Australia]]. The Delhi International Sanskrit Conference of 1972 is considered to be the first World Sanskrit Conference. So far it has been held in [[India]] four times (1972,1981,1997,2012).<ref>http://www.sanskritassociation.org/conferences.php</ref>
==History== [[File:ANCIENT_SANSKRIT_ON_HEMP_BASED_PAPER._HEMP_WAS_A_COMMON_AND_DURABLE_FIBRE_IN_THE_PRODUCTION_OF_%22RAG%22_PAPER_FROM_200_BCE_TO_THE_1850_AD.jpg|right|thumb|Ancient Sanskrit on Hemp based Paper. Hemp Fiber was commonly used in the production of paper from 200 BCE to the Late 1800's.]] According to the official web-site of the [[International Association of Sanskrit Studies]] (IASS), several [[Sanskrit]] scholars from major Indian universities perceived that the International Congress of Orientalists "did not allow sufficient scope for full discussion of Sanskrit and allied subjects". These scholars approached the [[Government of India]], which arranged to convene the first International Sanskrit Conference at [[New Delhi]] in March 1972. The next year, at the 29th International Congress of Orientalists, Sanskrit scholars from all over the world got together to form the IASS. The main responsibility of the IASS was to organise World Sanskrit Conferences at various places around the world. The 1972 New Delhi conference was retrospectively recognised as the "First World Sanskrit Conference".<ref name="IASS-20120412">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanskrit.nic.in/IASS/HOME_page.htm|title=INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF SANSKRIT STUDIES (IASS) |publisher=IASS |accessdate=12 April 2012|location=New Delhi}}</ref>
The sixteenth conference in Thailand in 2015 received unprecedented support from the Indian government.<ref name=ectimes24jun2015>{{cite news |last1=Chaudhury |first1=Dipanjan Roy |last2=Venugopal |first2=Vasudha|title=Government to send 250 Sanskrit scholars to participate in World Sanskrit Conference in Thailand |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-06-24/news/63783144_1_indian-embassy-scholars-world-sanskrit-conference|accessdate=29 July 2015 |agency=[[The Economic Times]] |date=24 June 2015}}</ref> In what some have called a "display of soft power", India sent a group of 250 Sanskrit scholars, led by [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|External Affairs Minister]] [[Sushma Swaraj]], who gave the inaugural address in Sanskrit.<ref name=ectimes24jun2015/> The conference was also supported by and held in honor of [[Maha Chakri Sirindhorn]], Princess of Thailand, who has supported Sanskrit education, and had received a master's degree in [[Pali]] and Sanskrit from [[Chulalongkorn University]].<ref name=princess30june/>
==Dates and venues== The first World Sanskrit Conference was held in [[Vigyan Bhavan]], New Delhi, India between 26–31 March 1972.<ref name="Welfare1980">{{cite book|author=India. Ministry of Education and Social Welfare|title=International Sanskrit Conference|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oEg9AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=1980|publisher=The Ministry|page=iii}}</ref> Dr. Ranganathan was its chairman.<ref name="Venkatasubramanian2010">{{cite book|author=T.K. Venkatasubramanian|title=Music as History in TamilNadu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pzurjfF3AE4C&pg=PA138|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=2010|publisher=Primus Books|isbn=978-93-80607-06-1|page=138}}</ref> Thereafter, conferences have been held as follows:
*[[Torino]], Italy, in June 1975.<ref name="Wayman1984">{{cite book|author=[[Alex Wayman]]|title=Buddhist Insight: Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BNIdOsp3KIgC&pg=PA417|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=1984|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=978-81-208-0675-7|page=417}}</ref> *[[Paris]], France, between 20–25 June 1977<ref name="Varma1993">{{cite book|author=Satya Vrat Varma|title=Nāyakanāyikāguṇālaṅkāra|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9vxjAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=1 January 1993|publisher=Eastern Book Linkers|isbn=978-81-85133-53-9 |page=13}}</ref> *[[Weimar]], German Democratic Republic, between 23–30 May 1979.<ref name="Morgenroth1986">{{cite book|author=Wolfgang Morgenroth|title=Sanskrit and world culture: proceedings of the Fourth World Sanskrit Conference of the International Association of Sanskrit Studies, Weimar, May 23-30, 1979|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gBMhAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=1986|publisher=Akademie-Verlag |page=3}}</ref> *[[Varanasi]], India in 1981.<ref name="UtpalaBailly1987">{{cite book|author1=Utpala|author2=Constantina Rhodes Bailly|title=Shaiva Devotional Songs of Kashmir: A Translation and Study of Utpaladeva's Shivastotravali|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J0xVjmU_jPUC&pg=PR9|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=1 June 1987|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-88706-492-0|page=9}}</ref> *[[Philadelphia]], United States, in 1984.<ref name="Goudriaan1992">{{cite book|author=Teun Goudriaan|title=Ritual and Speculation in Early Tantrism: Studies in Honour of André Padoux|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SvKkr0EjTP8C&pg=PR14|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=1992|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-0898-8|page=14}}</ref> *[[Leiden]], Netherlands, in 1987.<ref name="Barfoot2001">{{cite book|author=C. C. Barfoot|title=Aldous Huxley Between East and West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FC7E8-cg-4UC&pg=PA196|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=2001|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-1347-6|page=196}}</ref> *[[Vienna]], Austria; 27 August–2 September 1990.<ref>{{cite news|title=World Sanskrit Conference|work=The Indian Express|date=24 September 1990|page=6}}</ref> *[[Melbourne]], Australia, in January 1994.<ref name="Menski1998">{{cite book|author=Werner Menski|title=South Asians and the Dowry Problem|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_8OWbW8mnYC&pg=PA21|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=1998|publisher=Trentham Books|isbn=978-1-85856-141-7|page=21}}</ref> *[[Bangalore]], India, in January 1997.<ref name="Patil2002">{{cite book|author=Shankaragouda Hanamantagouda Patil|title=Community Dominance and Political Modernisation: The Lingayats|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R84n-Wv1S-8C&pg=PA79|accessdate=12 April 2012|year=2002|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-867-9|page=79}}</ref> *[[Turin]], Italy, in April 2000.<ref name="SOAS-20120412">{{cite web|url=http://www.soas.ac.uk/religions/events/comeandmeet/shivamurthy/|title=Shivamurthy Swami|last=Dawer BACK|first=John |publisher=SOAS, University of London|accessdate=12 April 2012|location=London}}</ref> *[[Helsinki]], Finland, in July 2003.<ref name="Wujastyk2009">{{cite book|author=Dominik Wujastyk|title=Mathematics And Medicine In Sanskrit|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XPKCregSrLEC&pg=PA1|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publishers|isbn=978-81-208-3246-6|page=1}}</ref> *[[Edinburgh]], United Kingdom, in July 2006.<ref name="Brodbeck2007">{{cite book|author=Simon Brodbeck|title=Gender and Narrative in the Mahābhārata|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mBRh7HPZhl4C&pg=PA315|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=19 September 2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-41540-8|page=315}}</ref> *[[Kyoto]], Japan, from 1 to 6 September 2009.<ref name="Singh2009">{{cite book|author=Rajendra Singh|title=Annual Review of South Asian Languages and Linguistics: 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xOGYIv8m3NQC&pg=PA150|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=12 December 2009|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-022559-4|page=150}}</ref> *[[New Delhi]], India from 5 to 10 January 2012.<ref name="WSC-20120412">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanskrit.nic.in/iass/wsc15.pdf|title=15th WORLD SANSKRIT CONFERENCE 5th to 10th January, 2012|accessdate=12 April 2012}}[http://www.sanskrit.nic.in/IASS/HOME_page.htm]</ref> *[[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] from 28 June to 2 July 2015.<ref name=princess30june>{{cite news |last1=NNT |title=World Sanskrit Conference held in honor of Princess Maha Chakri |url=http://www.pattayamail.com/news/world-sanskrit-conference-held-in-honor-of-princess-maha-chakri-48510 |accessdate=29 July 2015 |work=Battaya Mail |date=30 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=acadprogram2015>Conference Academic Program from Sanskrit Studies Centre, Bangkok: [http://www.sanskrit-silpakorn.org/images/pdf/Schedule-academic_programme.pdf 16th World Sanskrit Conference June 28 to July 2, 2015, Bangkok (Academic Program)] (accessed 29 July 2015</ref> *[[Vancouver]], Canada, from July 9 to July 13, 2018.<ref name="IASS-20121113">{{cite web|title=The 17th World Sanskrit Conference|url=http://wsc.ubcsanskrit.ca|publisher=University of British Columbia}}</ref>
===Future venues and dates===
*The eighteenth conference is scheduled to be held in [[Canberra]], [[Australia]] in 2021.<ref name="IASS-20121113"/>
== Controversies == Recent World Sanskrit Conferences have been sites of controversy.
# The 2015 conference in Bangkok was opened by Rajiv Malhotra, an author of popular books who does not hold a PhD in Indology or any related field.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/blogs/southasiamasala/2015/08/03/tigers-and-goats-a-quick-report-on-the-world-sanskrit-conference-bangkok-2015/|title=South Asia Masala » Tigers and Goats A quick report on the World Sanskrit Conference, Bangkok 2015|website=asiapacific.anu.edu.au|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref> Malhotra has been accused of plagiarism and is well-known for his ad hominem attacks on Indologists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://scroll.in/article/742022/upset-about-rajiv-malhotras-plagiarism-even-more-upset-about-distortions-of-my-work|title='Upset about Rajiv Malhotra’s plagiarism, even more upset about distortions of my work'|last=Nicholson|first=Andrew J.|work=Scroll.in|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-US}}</ref> # The 2018 conference in Vancouver featured a session titled "The Story of Our Sanskrit," where two female Sanskritists presented and a third female Sanskritist moderated. The session was plagued by sexist and casteist comments from an unruly audience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-opinion/how-to-move-a-mountain/article24683993.ece|title=How to move a mountain|last=Vajpeyi|first=Ananya|date=2018-08-14|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/life/world-sanskrit-conference-shows-that-sanskritic-scholarship-in-india-remains-afraid-of-gender-and-caste-4895051.html|title=World Sanskrit Conference shows that Sanskritic scholarship in India remains afraid of gender and caste - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref> In an email sent to the INDOLOGY listserv, the lead conference organizer, Dr. Adheesh Sathaye, publicly apologized for the "hooliganistic behaviour of some members of the audience."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://list.indology.info/pipermail/indology_list.indology.info/|title=The INDOLOGY Archives|website=list.indology.info|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref> Less than a week later, Dr. Sathaye retracted his apology via a note sent to the same listserv, thus prompting a debate about Hindutva influences within the discipline of Indology. # The World Sanskrit Conference has uncomfortable links with the Indian government, and recent conferences have given speaking platforms to Indian government officials.
==Proceedings== The proceedings of the WSC have been published as follows:<ref name="IASS-20121">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanskrit.nic.in/iassn11.pdf|title=NEWSLETTER OF THE INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF SANSKRIT STUDIES|last=Brockington|first=John |year=2012 |publisher=IASS|accessdate=13 April 2012|location=New Delhi |page=8}}</ref> #Delhi (1972) Conference were published in four volumes (vols I-III.1, Ministry of Education and SocialWelfare, New Delhi,1975–80; vols III.2-IV, [[Rashtriya Sanskrit Sansthan]], Delhi, 1981), #Weimar (1979) Conference in a volume entitled Sanskrit and World Culture (Akademie-Verlag, Berlin, 1986), those of the Varanasi Conference by the Rashtriya Sanskrit Sansthan, New Delhi, in 1985. #An IASS newsletter informs that the proceedings of the Leiden (1987) Conference in several volumes (Brill, Leiden, 1990–92); the Proceedings of the Helsinki (2003) and Edinburgh (2006) Conferences are in the process of publication by [[Motilal Banarsidass]], New Delhi. #The Proceedings of the World Sanskrit Conferences held at Turin (1975), Paris (1977), Philadelphia (1984), Vienna (1990), Melbourne (1994), Bangalore (1997), Turin (2000), Kyoto (2009) have been published in ''Indologica Taurinensia'', which is the official organ of the I.A.S.S. The journal contents are freely downloadable [http://www.indologica.com/].
==See also== *[[Sanskrit studies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite web |title=Sinological Conferences: ICANAS |url=http://www.umass.edu/wsp/sinology/conferences/icanas.html |publisher=Warring States Project - University of Massachusetts, Amherst |accessdate=13 November 2012}} *{{cite book |title=Islam and the West |first=Bernard |last=Lewis |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1993 |isbn=9780195090611 |pages=103–105 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=br74_99YqSIC&pg=PA103 |accessdate=13 November 2012}}
